3D Reconstruction Tutorial with Python and Meshroom
Quickly learn to create 3D models from photos, and master point cloud generation with Python + Meshroom (photogrammetry).

Time to move onto Stage 1: a quick (and dirty) introduction to photogrammetry.

1. Photogrammetry: introduction
So, photogrammetry is a powerful technique that allows the creation of 3D models from a series of 2D images.

Today, I will guide you on generating 3D point clouds using Python and Meshroom. The process involves capturing images, processing them in Meshroom to create a 3D model, and then using Python to manipulate and visualize the resulting point cloud, as illustrated below.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Now that you grasp what we are going to do from a high-level view, let us move on to stage 2.

2. Prerequisites
Before starting, ensure you have the following:

Press enter or click to view image in full size
The software and applications covered in photogrammetry tutorial by Florent Poux
The software and applications are covered in this tutorial. ¬©

This holds:

A camera (a smartphone camera can suffice)
A computer with Meshroom installed
Python installed on your computer
Libraries: open3d, numpy, matplotlib
You can install the necessary Python libraries using pip:

pip install open3d numpy matplotlib

Let us capture some images.

3. Capturing Images
The quality of your 3D model heavily depends on the quality and quantity of the images you capture. Follow these guidelines for the best results:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

How to capture good photos for 3D Reconstruction? ¬© 
Florent Poux, Ph.D.
If I have to describe a bit what that means:

Capture images with good lighting and minimal shadows.
Ensure the object is in focus in all pictures.
Take photos from multiple angles to cover all sides of the object.
Overlap between consecutive images should be around 60‚Äì80%.
With these four simple directions, you should be good to go and ready to move on to stage 4.

4. Processing Images with Meshroom
Great, you now have a bunch of images that you uploaded to a local drive folder on your computer. It is time to use Meshroom, as illustrated below:

Press enter or click to view image in full size
The Meshroom process in 4 steps. ¬© Florent Poux, Ph.D.
The Meshroom process in 4 steps. ¬© 
Florent Poux, Ph.D.
What you should do in detail is the following:

Open Meshroom: Launch Meshroom on your computer.
Create a New Project: Start a new project and import your images by dragging and dropping them into the Meshroom workspace.
Run the Pipeline: Click the ‚ÄúStart‚Äù button to run the default photogrammetry pipeline. Meshroom will process the images and generate a 3D model.
Inspect the Model: Once processing is complete, inspect the 3D model to ensure it meets your expectations.
After these steps, we can move on to stage 5: exporting our 3D dataset.

5. Exporting the Point Cloud
After generating the 3D model (yes, it is a model at this stage) in Meshroom, let us export the point cloud. If you look at my illustration below, this is what we do:

Press enter or click to view image in full size
How to export point clouds in Meshroom. ¬© Florent Poux, Ph.D.
How to export point clouds in Meshroom. ¬© 
Florent Poux, Ph.D.
In short, that means:

Select the Output: In the Meshroom interface, navigate to the ‚ÄúTexturing‚Äù node.
Export: Right-click on the ‚ÄúTexturing‚Äù node and select ‚ÄúExport‚Äù. Choose the format you prefer, such as .ply or .obj.
Great, now we can move on to the next stage: six.

ü¶ö Florent‚Äôs Note: At this stage, if you feel like something is not properly working, then I recommend checking out the tutorial hinted before, as this holds the various deep details that I am overlooking here for the sake of quick replication.

6. Visualizing the Point Cloud with Python
Now that you have the point cloud file, you can use Python to visualize it. Below is a sample script using open3d:

import open3d as o3d
And to visualize your point cloud:

pcd = o3d.io.read_point_cloud("path_to_your_point_cloud.ply")
o3d.visualization.draw_geometries([pcd])

Not bad, hun?

7. Conclusion
Generating 3D point clouds using Python and Meshroom is a straightforward process that leverages the power of photogrammetry. By following the steps outlined in this document, you can create detailed 3D models from simple 2D images and visualize them using Python.
